image.altText: A composite image of two men and a woman, separated by paper tears.

items.synopsis: Across Australia, more than 46,000 clients under state control are prevented by law from being identified, but there are growing calls for change. Some say gag laws that were designed to protect vulnerable people are shielding the agencies involved from scrutiny.

title.children: Memories sent to the tip, refused money for Christmas — and all by order of the state

image.altText: Baby Jarrod at time of second visit to Caboolture hospital in October 2022. The child has a rash around his mouth and face

items.synopsis: Baby Jarrod was in "absolute agony" when his parents took him to the emergency department two days in a row. He only received a diagnosis when his father called in Ryan's Rule.

title.children: Baby in 'absolute agony' turned away days after assurances hospital was providing best possible care

image.altText: A small submersible plunging into the water.

items.synopsis: Deep in the waters of the Atlantic Ocean, a search is underway for a submersible that was carrying five people when it disappeared on an expedition to the wreckage of the Titanic.

title.children: Frantic search as Titanic submersible disappears underwater with five people and 96 hours' oxygen

image.altText: Three people stand in blizzard at Mount Hotham.

items.synopsis: A polar air mass sends the mercury plunging over south-eastern Australia on Tuesday and Wednesday, while a thick rain band is brewing in the north-west and set to deliver falls across the country by the end of the week.

title.children: South-eastern Australia to shiver through prolonged frosty weather, with 'tropical' rain on the way

image.altText: A sign post with pathways saying Yes and No against a blue sky

items.synopsis: For the first time in 24 years, Australians are heading to the polls to decide on a change to the constitution. Legislation setting up a referendum on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament passed the Senate on Monday, meaning a referendum has to be held before the end of the year.

title.children: It's official — the Voice referendum is happening. Here's what comes next

image.altText: A collage of black and white images of a man smiling in a suit and tie, holding a rifle, and in a passport-style photo.

items.synopsis: The untold spy story of a mole in ASIO's ranks who sold the Soviets highly classified intelligence and got away with it.

title.children: 'This guy flew under the radar': The mole embedded in the heart of Australia's spy agency

image.altText: Putin says he may seize 'buffer zone' in Ukraine

items.synopsis: Vladimir Putin has a brutal new strategy to ensure Russia's invasion of Ukraine is "a long process". It means there are now strategic and humanitarian imperatives for the West to defeat Putin's latest theory of victory, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Vladimir Putin's plan to win quickly in Ukraine failed. Russia is now implementing an even more brutal strategy

image.altText: Steve Smith rolls on the ground

items.synopsis: England started day four of the first Ashes Test with a wild reverse ramp from Joe Root, and never looked back on a thrilling day of Test cricket. Here's the five things you missed overnight.

title.children: Five quick hits — Root's unorthodox batting raises eyebrows and Bairstow lets Khawaja off

image.altText: Pat Cummins clenches fists and yells in delight as Ben Stokes walks off behind him

items.synopsis: Australia has raised eyebrows with its anti-Bazball measures in the first Ashes Test at Edgbaston, but all the spread fields and conservative bowling could yet add up to a famous win.

title.children: Australia and England follow different paths to meet for a thrilling climax to Edgbaston Test

image.altText: A man speaking on a podium

items.synopsis: For the first time, the Australian government will sponsor a poet to represent the country, but the details of how they will be selected remain a mystery.

title.children: Australia's first poet laureate offers a chance to articulate 'who we are'. But how will they be chosen?

image.altText: A middle-aged man in jeans and a jacket sits in a chair and smiles. In front is a table with Titanic Expedition written on it

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happened.

title.children: Wealthy businessman missing on Titanic explorer, and Putin critic Navalny's new trial begins. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: A chaotic scene with several people on the ground in a hospital, all of them with blurred faces.

items.synopsis: An expert in medical law warns WA health workers they need to be aware they can not legally keep someone in hospital if they do not want to be there.

title.children: Warning for WA health workers over keeping patients in hospital against their will

image.altText: Artist Montana McStay with her artwork

items.synopsis: Gunaikurnai woman Montana McStay is helping Indigenous children connect with their culture through weaving, bead making, painting and other art forms.

title.children: Gippsland artist helping disadvantaged First Nations students learn about their culture

image.altText: A young woman with long blonde hair stands outside, wearing a white jumper and holding books unde rher arm

items.synopsis: Jasmine didn’t have a parental figure to help her navigate the tax system or buy household basics. But she's pleased other teens in foster care may soon have support for longer under law reform promised across the country.

title.children: After going through 'dark days' when she left foster care at 18, Jasmin is studying to become a paramedic

image.altText: A woman wearing a white turtle neck and black blazer stands smiling in a restaurant.

items.synopsis: North Korea's "Jangmadang Generation" grew up facing immense hardship after a devastating famine. Now those fortunate few who escaped find the skills they used to survive rather helpful in capitalist South Korea.

title.children: Chan Yang built a thriving secret business in North Korea. Then she made a daring bid for freedom

image.altText: Man in suit stands in front of tree smiling at camera.

items.synopsis: Victorian councillors want more training for those new to local government ahead of the 2024 elections, with one suggesting more thorough background checks.

title.children: Councillor says election process is too easy amid calls for more governance training

image.altText: Women in black shirt holding flyer looks sad

items.synopsis: Carrie-Ann Adams's symptoms were mistaken for the flu — but in reality, she was dying of bowel cancer and had 12 weeks to live.

title.children: Ann says lowering the bowel cancer screening age could have saved her 41yo daughter's life

image.altText: A clothing store in Sydney advertises for staff in its shopfront.

items.synopsis: While economic growth is slowing, the jobs market hasn't been this strong since the 1950s. Unemployment is plumbing half century lows — a development that has everyone from central banks to politicians scratching their heads, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Interest rates aren't working in the way we thought they would and it's not clear why

image.altText: Greg Pickhaver

items.synopsis: He's one half of much-loved comedy duo Roy and HG, but Greig Pickhaver says a diagnosis of dyslexia was both a "blessing and a curse" as he carved out a successful career "making up things on the spot".

title.children: Greig 'HG Nelson' Pickhaver on why planning out life is 'a complete crock'

image.altText: Man wearing black t-shirt stands on balcony with ocean in the background, folding his arms.

items.synopsis: The International Transport Workers' Federation says inspections of boats at NSW ports raise serious concerns about pay and conditions.

title.children: Union says 'modern slavery' must end as seafarer wage crackdown finds $4 million owed to workers

image.altText: Close up of red and green numbers on ASX board

items.synopsis: The Australian share market rises to a fresh seven-week high as investors await a detailed account of what the Reserve Bank board discussed when it decided to lift interest rates to an 11-year high earlier this month. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX opens higher ahead of Reserve Bank minutes being released

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market has risen slightly in morning trade, with the ASX 200 up 0.3% to 7,317 points. Australia's benchmark stock index is trading at its highest level since May 1. Energy and materials are the best performing sectors, driven by gains across Pilbara Minerals (+2.6%), Whitehaven Coal (+1.3%) and AGL Energy (+1%). On the flip side, consumer discretionary stocks are among the worst performers, including Premier Investments (-4.7%), Domino's Pizza (-2.2%) and Collins Foods (-1.4%). Lithium stock Lake Resources has plunged 17.1% (on top of yesterday's 20% slump). It was after the company revealed its major lithium project in Argentina will be delayed by six years —  and cost twice as much as it originally planned.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mining and energy stocks boost ASX to seven-week high

children.content: The local share market has risen slightly in morning trade, with the ASX 200 up 0.3% to 7,317 points.
Australia's benchmark stock index is trading at its highest level since May 1.
Energy and materials are the best performing sectors, driven by gains across Pilbara Minerals (+2.6%), Whitehaven Coal (+1.3%) and AGL Energy (+1%).
On the flip side, consumer discretionary stocks are among the worst performers, including Premier Investments (-4.7%), Domino's Pizza (-2.2%) and Collins Foods (-1.4%).

Lithium stock Lake Resources has plunged 17.1% (on top of yesterday's 20% slump). It was after the company revealed its major lithium project in Argentina will be delayed by six years —  and cost twice as much as it originally planned.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! I'll be here to guide you through today's latest business and economic news. The Australian share market is currently at a seven-week high, and likely to start the day higher (with SPI futures up 0.2%). That's despite an overnight fall on European markets and Wall Street being closed for the Juneteenth public holiday (commemorating the emancipation of African Americans from slavery). Investors are looking out for the Reserve Bank meeting minutes, which are out at 11:30am AEST. They will provide greater detail on why the RBA decided to lift the cash rate target to 4.1% earlier this month (a decision which surprised markets). Later today, the RBA's deputy governor Michele Bullock will give a speech on " Achieving Full Employment ", at an event hosted by the Australian Industry Group in Newcastle. Overseas, investors are looking closely at China as there's speculation our biggest trading partner will pump more stimlus into its slowing economy. The People's Bank of China is expected to cut its benchmark loan prime interest rates today, following a similar reduction in medium-term lending rates last week.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX likely to rise, ahead of Reserve Bank minutes

children.content: Good morning! I'll be here to guide you through today's latest business and economic news.
The Australian share market is currently at a seven-week high, and likely to start the day higher (with SPI futures up 0.2%).
That's despite an overnight fall on European markets and Wall Street being closed for the Juneteenth public holiday (commemorating the emancipation of African Americans from slavery).
Investors are looking out for the Reserve Bank meeting minutes, which are out at 11:30am AEST.
They will provide greater detail on why the RBA decided to lift the cash rate target to 4.1% earlier this month (a decision which surprised markets).
Later today, the RBA's deputy governor Michele Bullock will give a speech on "
", at an event hosted by the Australian Industry Group in Newcastle.

image.altText: An aerial view of houses in Hobart, Tasmania.

items.synopsis: Hobart City Council has voted to double the rates charged for short-stay accommodation properties in a bid to get more properties back on the long-term rental market.

title.children: Hobart council doubles rates for short-stay owners to boost housing stocks

image.altText: A white woman with grey hair and blue eyes looks into the camera.

items.synopsis: Set amid the sexism of the 60s, Lessons in Chemistry and its fiery protagonist have captured hearts around the world.

title.children: Bonnie Garmus got 98 rejections from book agents. Then she wrote a global bestseller

image.altText: Bill Shorten

items.synopsis: The actions of Australia's politicians in parliament come under fire on Q+A after a week that saw David Van leave the Liberals and Katy Gallagher grilled by the Coalition.

title.children: 'Toxic': Shorten takes aim at behaviour of politicians in parliament

image.altText: Ollie Robinson holds his arms out in celebration as Joe Root runs towards him

items.synopsis: Late wickets help England gain the upper hand of an enthralling first Ashes Test at Edgbaston, with Australia needing 174 more runs to win with seven wickets remaining.

title.children: Australia's night watchman makes it through late day-four flurry, setting up thrilling finale to first Ashes Test

image.altText: Ukrainian soldiers hold up yellow-and-blue national flags.

items.synopsis: Ukraine says it has made another gain in its counteroffensive, driving Russian forces out of the village of Piatykhatky, which is significant for being near the most direct route to the Azov Sea coast.

title.children: Ukraine claims eight villages now retaken, with 'biggest blow' in offensive yet to come

image.altText: head of a shimmering blue fish against a black background

items.synopsis: Fish around the world have declined in size as water temperatures warm, but the reason why is poorly understood. Our experiments offer some clues as we prepare for a warmer future with smaller fish.

title.children: Why are all the fish shrinking?

image.altText: Gouldian finch eat gamba grass.

items.synopsis: Federal Environment Minister Tanya Plibersek concedes the development will have "significant" impacts on the endangered Gouldian finch, but says that is acceptable if changes are made to approval conditions.

title.children: Residents devastated after environment minister approves housing project that could impact Gouldian finches

image.altText: Nick Kyrgios serves against Daniil Medvedev at the Montreal Masters tennis tournament.

items.synopsis: Nick Kyrgios has pulled out of the grass-court tournament in Halle with a knee injury, but says he still hopes to be fit to play Wimbledon.

title.children: Nick Kyrgios out of Halle with knee injury but still hopes to play Wimbledon

image.altText: An AFL player eyes the football he holds in one hand as he prepares to kick.

items.synopsis: Hawthorn will be without captain James Sicily for their next three AFL matches after his appeal against a suspension for rough conduct was rejected.

title.children: Hawks skipper James Sicily fails in AFL suspension appeal

image.altText: Bottlenose dolphin calf Dusty swims with mum Jinx at Sea World on the Gold Coast

items.synopsis: The UN has adopted the world's first treaty to protect the high seas and preserve marine biodiversity in international waters, marking a milestone after nearly 20 years of effort, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres announced Monday.

title.children: UN adopts world's first treaty to protect marine biodiversity
